Hi,

[I'm replying to the whole junit mailing list in order to not waste
any effort put into the discussion.]


On 10/31/06, Bo Liu <hitliubo@...> wrote:
> I'm afraid you do not understand me totally. [...] I want to display some
> information at Type column in JUnitReport. But it seems that only the
> Assert Fail/Error information can be displayed. I want to display some
> Assert Sucessful information which I need in order to make the report
> more detailed.

I understood what you wanted to do but, due to the way JUnit works,
it's not possible without some heavy lifting. The basic issue is that
there's no "event" created for a successful assertion. Only exceptions
thrown by the code under test or the test method itself create a
"failure" event.

To put it another way, there's no way for JUnit to tell whether you
executed one, two or a dozen assertions somewhere inside your test
method. That is, unless you instrument the bytecode somehow (with
which I cannot help since it's really not my field of expertise) and
add the necessary logging to where the assertion methods are invoked.


On 10/31/06, Bo Liu <hitliubo@...> wrote:
> A guy said I could achieve my goal though modifying XSL.
> But I've no idea about that.

Me neither. Since the XML document being processed with the XSL
stylesheet doesn't contain any information about assertions that were
executed successfully, I really cannot imagine how the XSL could come
up with that information on its own...


Lasse
